date: stated on March 9, 2016 in the Democratic debate at Miami Dade College:
title: Saunders said that Clinton supported the return of undocumented children.
text: In the democratic presidential debate at Miami-Dade College, Vermont-Sen. Bernie Sanders was intended to show that he, not former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, was the best friend of undocumented immigrants. Minister Clinton said, send them back." Clinton said that this is not a fair summary. The Sanders campaign said that they got their information from an interview by Clinton with Christian Amanpour on CNN in June 2014. We have children at the age of five and six who came from Central America. We need to do more to provide border security in southern Mexico." Amanpur: "So, you're saying they should be returned now?" The distinguished fact-finding bloggers mentioned on January 10, 2021 in the story of "The Rebel Law - General Flynn will be appointed Vice-President." • January 11, 2021 Clinton: "Well, they should be returned as soon as it is possible to identify the responsible adults in their families, because there are concerns about whether they should all be returned. But I believe that everyone who can be reunited with their families." Clinton made two points in that last answer. It's not as simple as saying "send them again," but this was certainly the result of her support in some cases. Specifically, she said that they should be returned if the Government could identify responsible adults for their care. She allowed that it might not be possible to send them all home. However, she referred to a preference. "I believe that all those who can be reunited with their families," said Clinton. It should be noted that at that time the Department actively pursued a policy of discouraging children and adolescents in Central America from trying to take this journey in the first place. The Government had open letters printed in the local newspapers and paid for the propaganda that dispelled any myth that these young people would be allowed to stay if they were able to cross the border. In July 2014, the White House indicated that it would seek funds to accelerate the return of most of the children who had been stopped at the United States border.
